name: Park Sung-bae
summary: Park Sung-bae is a Korean fiber scientist who contributed to the development of advanced textile fibers in South Korea. His research on high-performance fibers and smart textiles helped Korea's textile industry transition from basic manufacturing to advanced materials production.

name: Yun Cheol-ho
summary: Yun Cheol-ho was a Korean ceramic engineer who advanced Korea's ceramics industry from traditional pottery to advanced technical ceramics. His research on electronic ceramics and piezoelectric materials contributed to Korea's electronics industry, supplying key components for semiconductor and display manufacturing.

name: Choi Dong-hee
summary: Choi Dong-hee is a Korean optical engineer who has contributed to the development of photonic devices and optical communication systems. His research on optical components and photonic integrated circuits has supported Korea's telecommunications infrastructure development.

name: Sung Nak-in
summary: Sung Nak-in is a Korean structural engineer who contributed to the design of major infrastructure projects in South Korea, including high-rise buildings and bridge systems. He served as president of Seoul National University and has been influential in Korean engineering education and research policy.
timeline: Became president of Seoul National University

name: Chae Kun-sik
summary: Chae Kun-sik was a Korean food scientist who scientifically studied Korean traditional fermented foods including doenjang, gochujang, and jeotgal. His research on fermentation microbiology helped standardize Korean fermented food production while preserving traditional flavors and health benefits.
timeline: Contributed to Korean food industry standards

name: Kim Whan-ki
summary: Kim Whan-ki was Korea's most important abstract painter whose work explored the intersection of Korean traditional aesthetics and modern abstraction. While not a scientist, his systematic study of color, light, and spatial perception demonstrated a scientific approach to art that influenced Korean visual culture and design.
timeline: Born in Jeungdo, South Jeolla Province

name: Park Il-beom
summary: Park Il-beom is a Korean control systems engineer who developed automation and control technologies for Korean manufacturing industries. His research on industrial robot control systems and factory automation contributed to Korea's manufacturing productivity revolution.
timeline: Earned PhD in control systems engineering

name: Hong Soon-young
summary: Hong Soon-young is a Korean chemical engineer who contributed to the development of South Korea's petrochemical industry. His research on catalytic cracking and polymer production processes helped establish Korea as one of the world's largest petrochemical producers.

name: Shim Jae-duck
summary: Shim Jae-duck was a Korean environmental scientist who spent decades cleaning and restoring Korean rivers, particularly through the Nakdong River restoration project. His citizen science approach to river monitoring and his environmental advocacy helped raise awareness of water pollution in South Korea.

name: Izumi Masayoshi
summary: Although Izumi Shigechiyo was claimed to be the world's oldest verified living person at 120 years, verification was disputed. His case sparked research interest in Japanese longevity, contributing to studies of Okinawan diet, genetics, and lifestyle factors that make Japan one of the world's longest-lived populations.

name: Kano Jigoro
summary: Kano Jigoro founded judo in 1882 by applying scientific principles of leverage, balance, and biomechanics to traditional jujutsu. He systematically analyzed the physics of throwing, grappling, and falling techniques. His scientific approach to martial arts training and physical education influenced sports science worldwide.
timeline: Judo proved effective against traditional jujutsu
Became first Asian member of International Olympic Committee
Died aboard ship returning from IOC meeting

name: Tomoko Ohta
summary: Tomoko Ohta is a Japanese evolutionary biologist who developed the nearly neutral theory of molecular evolution, a refinement of Motoo Kimura's neutral theory. Her theory proposes that slightly deleterious mutations, rather than strictly neutral ones, play a major role in evolution. This model better explains observed patterns of molecular evolution.
timeline: Earned PhD from North Carolina State University
Joined National Institute of Genetics, Mishima
Proposed nearly neutral theory of molecular evolution

name: Osamu Nagata
summary: Osamu Nagata was a Japanese earthquake engineer who developed seismic isolation systems for nuclear power plants and critical infrastructure. His engineering innovations in base isolation and energy absorption devices helped protect vital facilities during major earthquakes.
timeline: Developed isolation systems for nuclear facilities
Technology proved effective in Kobe earthquake

name: Kawasaki Tomisaku
summary: Kawasaki Tomisaku was a Japanese pediatrician who first identified Kawasaki disease in 1967, a childhood illness causing inflammation of blood vessels throughout the body. His careful clinical observation and documentation of 50 cases established a new disease entity that affects children worldwide. Untreated, it can cause coronary artery problems.
timeline: Graduated from Chiba University Medical School
Observed first case of unusual childhood illness

name: Ohtake Masaru
summary: Ohtake Masaru was a Japanese fisheries scientist who pioneered the cultivation of yellowtail (hamachi) and other commercial fish species. His aquaculture techniques transformed Japanese fish farming from small-scale operations to a major industry, making Japan a global leader in aquaculture technology.

name: Yamada Kohei
summary: Yamada Kohei was a Japanese fermentation scientist who developed industrial fermentation processes for producing amino acids, vitamins, and other bioactive compounds. His work at Kyoto University advanced Japan's biotechnology industry, particularly in the production of glutamic acid and other food ingredients.

name: Wu Lien-teh
summary: Wu Lien-teh was a Malaysian-Chinese physician who contained the Manchurian plague epidemic of 1910-1911, saving millions of lives. He was the first to identify the pneumonic plague transmission route and invented the precursor to the N95 surgical mask. He was nominated for the Nobel Prize in 1935. He is considered the father of modern Chinese public health.
timeline: Sent to combat Manchurian plague epidemic

name: Huang Wei
summary: Huang Wei is a Chinese materials scientist who has made significant contributions to organic optoelectronics at Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications. His research on organic light-emitting materials, flexible electronics, and bioelectronics has advanced China's capabilities in next-generation display and wearable technologies.
timeline: Joined Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications
Elected to Chinese Academy of Sciences

name: Li Ning
summary: Li Ning is a Chinese agricultural biotechnologist at China Agricultural University who has worked on transgenic livestock and cloning technology. His research on genetically modified animals aimed at improving agricultural productivity, though he also faced legal controversies regarding fund misuse.

name: Li Zhengdao
summary: Already covered - see Li Tsung-Dao. Duplicate check.

name: Wei Baoming
summary: Wei Baoming is a Chinese marine scientist who made significant contributions to fish genetics and breeding at the Chinese Academy of Fishery Sciences. His work on selective breeding of commercially important fish species has improved aquaculture productivity in China, the world's largest aquaculture producer.

name: Shi Changxu
summary: Shi Changxu was a Chinese materials scientist known as the 'Father of Chinese Superalloys.' He developed high-temperature alloys essential for jet engines and gas turbines, enabling China's aerospace and power generation industries. His superalloy research reduced China's dependence on imported materials for critical applications.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Notre Dame
Developed nickel-based superalloys for Chinese jet engines

name: Gong Sheng
summary: Gong Sheng is a Chinese computer scientist who was one of the pioneers of artificial intelligence research in China. His early work on pattern recognition and machine learning helped establish the foundations for China's now-thriving AI industry. He trained many of China's leading AI researchers.
timeline: Began AI research after Cultural Revolution
Trained next generation of Chinese AI researchers

name: Wu Hao
summary: Wu Hao is a Chinese-American structural biologist at Boston Children's Hospital and Harvard Medical School who has determined the molecular structures of key immune system proteins. Her work on innate immunity signaling pathways has advanced understanding of inflammatory diseases and infection response.

name: Zhi-Xun Shen
summary: Zhi-Xun Shen is a Chinese-American physicist at Stanford University who is an expert in angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES). His work has been crucial for understanding high-temperature superconductors, topological insulators, and other exotic quantum materials. He is one of the most cited physicists in condensed matter.
timeline: Advanced ARPES techniques for quantum materials

name: Yang Wei
summary: Yang Wei is a Chinese mechanical engineer who has made significant contributions to fracture mechanics and computational solid mechanics. He served as president of Zhejiang University and has been influential in Chinese engineering education reform. His research on damage mechanics has applications in aerospace and infrastructure safety.

name: Gao Jian
summary: Gao Jian is a Chinese physicist who contributed to the discovery of iron-based superconductors. His research on the 1111-type iron pnictide superconductors advanced understanding of the mechanism behind superconductivity in these new materials and established new records for critical temperatures.
timeline: Advanced understanding of iron pnictide superconductivity

name: Shyam Sunder Pattanayak
summary: Shyam Sunder Pattanayak is an Indian agricultural engineer who developed improved micro-irrigation systems for Indian farmers. His drip irrigation designs adapted to Indian conditions have helped conserve water while increasing crop yields in water-scarce regions of India.

name: Rajagopala Chidambaram
summary: Rajagopala Chidambaram is an Indian nuclear physicist who served as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission and principal scientific adviser to the Indian government. He played key roles in India's nuclear tests, including Pokhran-I (1974) and Pokhran-II (1998). He also made significant contributions to crystallography and high-pressure physics.
timeline: Born in Chengalpet, Tamil Nadu, India
Earned PhD from Indian Institute of Science
Key role in Smiling Buddha nuclear test
Became principal scientific adviser to government

name: Anil Kakodkar
summary: Anil Kakodkar is an Indian nuclear scientist who served as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission. He designed the CIRUS reactor modifications and advanced India's thorium utilization program. He led the development of the Advanced Heavy Water Reactor (AHWR) designed to use India's vast thorium reserves for nuclear power.
timeline: Born in Barwani, Madhya Pradesh, India
Became chairman of Atomic Energy Commission

name: Krishnaswamy Kasturirangan
summary: Krishnaswamy Kasturirangan is an Indian space scientist who served as chairman of the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO). Under his leadership, ISRO launched the Chandrayaan-1 Moon mission concept and advanced India's satellite technology. He also contributed to X-ray astronomy research and chaired India's education reform committee.
timeline: Earned PhD in experimental high-energy astronomy
Launched multiple communication and remote sensing satellites

name: Mylswamy Annadurai
summary: Mylswamy Annadurai is an Indian aerospace engineer known as 'Moon Man of India' for his role as project director of Chandrayaan-1, India's first Moon mission. He also directed the Mars Orbiter Mission (Mangalyaan). His low-cost space mission designs demonstrated that developing countries can conduct planetary exploration affordably.
timeline: Born in Kodhavadi, Tamil Nadu, India
Chandrayaan-1 launched, discovered water on Moon
Mangalyaan entered Mars orbit (first attempt success)

name: K. Sivan
summary: K. Sivan is an Indian aerospace engineer who served as chairman of ISRO and led the development of the cryogenic rocket engine for India's GSLV Mk III. Known as the 'Rocket Man,' he developed the vikas engine used in ISRO's launch vehicles. Under his leadership, ISRO launched Chandrayaan-2 and the record 104-satellite PSLV mission.
timeline: Born in Sarakkalvilai, Tamil Nadu, India
Joined ISRO Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre
Became director of Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre

name: Tessy Thomas
summary: Already covered. Duplicate check.

name: Park Won-soon
summary: While Park Won-soon was primarily a lawyer and politician who served as Mayor of Seoul, he promoted Seoul as a smart city and advanced urban technology innovation. Under his leadership, Seoul became a global model for urban technology implementation including open data initiatives and smart city infrastructure.

name: Yukichi Fukuzawa
summary: Yukichi Fukuzawa was a Japanese educator and writer who founded Keio University and is considered the father of Japanese modernization. He promoted Western science and technology through his books, especially Gakumon no Susume (An Encouragement of Learning). His systematic introduction of Western scientific concepts to Japan was transformative. His face appears on the ¥10,000 note.
timeline: Founded school that became Keio University
Published Seiyo Jijo (Conditions in the West)

name: Tanaka Giichi
summary: While primarily a military and political figure, Tanaka Giichi as Prime Minister promoted Japan's industrial and technological development in the 1920s. His government supported scientific research institutions and military technology development that advanced Japan's engineering capabilities during the interwar period.

name: Hayami Akira
summary: Hayami Akira is a Japanese historical demographer who pioneered the study of Japan's pre-modern population using Buddhist temple death registers (shumon aratame cho). His quantitative approach revealed that Tokugawa-era Japan had sophisticated demographic patterns, including population control and urbanization rates comparable to pre-industrial Europe.

name: Imanishi Kinji
summary: Already covered - see Kinji Imanishi. Duplicate check.

name: Nishi Amane
summary: Nishi Amane was a Japanese philosopher and scholar who introduced Western philosophy and scientific methodology to Japan. He coined many Japanese terms for Western philosophical and scientific concepts, including the Japanese words for 'philosophy,' 'aesthetics,' and 'psychology.' His terminology enabled Japanese to engage with Western science.
timeline: Coined Japanese terms for Western scientific concepts

name: Tetsuro Watsuji
summary: Watsuji Tetsuro was a Japanese philosopher who developed a cultural climatology linking geography and climate to cultural development. His 1935 work Fudo (Climate and Culture) systematically analyzed how different climate types shape human societies and their technological development, bridging natural and social sciences.

name: Nishida Kitaro
summary: Nishida Kitaro was Japan's most important modern philosopher who sought to integrate Eastern and Western thought. While primarily a philosopher, his concept of 'place' (basho) and 'absolute nothingness' influenced Japanese approaches to theoretical physics and mathematics, creating a unique philosophical framework for understanding scientific inquiry.

name: Kim Beopmin
summary: Kim Beopmin was one of the first Koreans to study modern physics. He earned a PhD in physics from Japan and returned to Korea to establish physics education programs. He was instrumental in building the foundation for Korean physics research during a period when Korea had virtually no modern scientific infrastructure.
timeline: Returned to Korea to teach physics

name: Yi Sang-seol
summary: Yi Sang-seol was a late Joseon Dynasty mathematician and independence activist who attempted to modernize Korean mathematics education by integrating Western mathematical methods with traditional Korean approaches. He also served as a diplomat seeking international support for Korean sovereignty.
timeline: Sent to The Hague as Korean emissary

name: Pak Hyeokkose
summary: Pak Hyeokkose was the legendary founder of the Silla kingdom in 57 BC. While a mythical figure, the Silla kingdom he reportedly founded later produced remarkable scientific and technological achievements including the Cheomseongdae observatory (the oldest surviving astronomical observatory in East Asia) and advanced metallurgical techniques.
timeline: Founded Silla kingdom according to legend

name: Kim Hyun-jun
summary: Kim Hyun-jun is a Korean medical engineer who has contributed to the development of robotic surgery systems in South Korea. His research on surgical robotics has helped Korea develop indigenous robotic surgery platforms, advancing minimally invasive surgical techniques and reducing Korea's dependence on imported surgical robots.

name: Hwang Ho-ik
summary: Hwang Ho-ik is a Korean electrical power engineer who contributed to the development and expansion of South Korea's electrical power grid. His work on high-voltage transmission systems and grid stability helped electrify Korea during its rapid industrialization period, supporting the country's economic miracle.
timeline: Contributed to Korean power grid expansion

name: Choi Moon-kyu
summary: Choi Moon-kyu is a Korean aerospace engineer who contributed to the development of liquid rocket engines for the KSLV (Korea Space Launch Vehicle). His propulsion research helped Korea develop indigenous rocket technology, culminating in the successful launch of the Nuri rocket (KSLV-II).
timeline: Contributed to KSLV liquid rocket engine
Nuri rocket successfully launched payload to orbit

name: Joo Gyeong-cheol
summary: Joo Gyeong-cheol is a Korean nuclear fusion scientist who has contributed to plasma physics research at the Korea Institute of Fusion Energy. His work on plasma confinement and heating systems for the KSTAR tokamak has been important for advancing Korea's fusion energy research capabilities.
timeline: Contributed to KSTAR first plasma achievement

name: Yoon Boo-geun
summary: Yoon Boo-geun is a Korean electronics engineer who served as CEO of Samsung Electronics' consumer electronics division and contributed to the development of Samsung's display and semiconductor technologies. His technical leadership helped Samsung become the world's largest electronics manufacturer.
timeline: Served as CEO of Samsung consumer electronics
Contributed to Samsung's global technology leadership

name: Cho Yang-ho
summary: Cho Yang-ho was a Korean aviation executive who served as chairman of Korean Air and the Hanjin Group. Under his leadership, Korean Air became one of the world's largest airlines and expanded into aerospace manufacturing, contributing to Korea's aviation technology development. Hanjin also built major infrastructure projects.

name: Song Ho-keun
summary: Song Ho-keun is a Korean sociologist at Seoul National University who has studied the social impacts of Korea's rapid technological development. His research on how technology shapes Korean society and labor markets has influenced Korean technology policy, particularly regarding automation and digital transformation.
timeline: Published on technology and Korean society

name: Kim Jeong-wook
summary: Kim Jeong-wook is a Korean physician who served as Director of the Global Influenza Programme at the World Health Organization. He played key roles in international responses to avian influenza and pandemic preparedness. His work on influenza surveillance systems has strengthened global capacity to detect and respond to pandemic threats.

name: Pak Mun-su
summary: Pak Mun-su was a Joseon Dynasty government official famous as an Amhaeng-eosa (secret royal inspector) who traveled the country investigating corruption and helping common people. While not a scientist, his systematic investigative methods for gathering evidence and his detailed documentation of social conditions anticipated modern social science field research.
timeline: Appointed as Amhaeng-eosa by King Yeongjo
